articles.headline: They Got 2012 Right. What About 2013?
articles.snippet: Experts who were accurate about 2012 offered their thoughts on stocks, bonds and real estate for this year.
articles.abstract: Experts who were accurate about 2012 offered their thoughts on stocks, bonds and real estate for this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: To many politicians, the deal that raised taxes on the wealthy and averted the fiscal cliff was a sellout, a cop-out, a Band-Aid — in short, nothing good. And now the debt ceiling showdown is looming. So why have stock investors cheered, pushing the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index to five-year highs?

articles.headline: Smartphones Become Life’s Remote Control
articles.snippet: At the Consumer Electronics Show, many app-powered accessories are on display that allow consumers to turn off lights, unlock doors or monitor their blood pressure.
articles.abstract: At the Consumer Electronics Show, many app-powered accessories are on display that allow consumers to turn off lights, unlock doors or monitor their blood pressure.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The smartphone is no longer just a portable computer in your pocket. It has become the remote control for your life.

articles.headline: A Trail of Bullet Casings Leads From Africa’s Wars Back to Iran
articles.snippet: Researchers worked for years to locate the source of rifle and machine-gun ammunition in war-torn regions. The manufacturer was not one of Africa’s usual suspects.
articles.abstract: Researchers worked for years to locate the source of rifle and machine-gun ammunition in war-torn regions. The manufacturer was not one of Africa’s usual suspects.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first clues appeared in Kenya, Uganda and what is now South Sudan. A British arms researcher surveying ammunition used by government forces and civilian militias in 2006 found Kalashnikov rifle cartridges he had not seen before. The ammunition bore no factory code, suggesting that its manufacturer hoped to avoid detection.

articles.headline: A Shocking Death, a Financial Lesson and Help for Others
articles.snippet: After Chanel Reynolds’s 43-year-old husband died in a bicycling accident, she had to suddenly face the financial tasks that grown-ups are supposed to have completed by middle age.
articles.abstract: After Chanel Reynolds’s 43-year-old husband died in a bicycling accident, she had to suddenly face the financial tasks that grown-ups are supposed to have completed by middle age.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE

articles.headline: Unions Back Revisions of Labor Law in France
articles.snippet: Unions and the main employers’ lobby settled on new rules that would overhaul swaths of the rigid labor market and restore France’s international allure as a place to do business.
articles.abstract: Unions and the main employers’ lobby settled on new rules that would overhaul swaths of the rigid labor market and restore France’s international allure as a place to do business.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — French labor unions and business leaders struck a deal on Friday to overhaul swaths of France’s notoriously rigid labor market, moving to tame some of the most confounding rules in the 3,200-page labor code as the country tries to increase its competitiveness and curb unemployment.

articles.headline: Veterans and Senate Buddies, Until Another War Split Them
articles.snippet: Two iconoclastic senators — Chuck Hagel and John McCain — shared a military background and a similar worldview, and they used to be close. What happened? Accounts differ.
articles.abstract: Two iconoclastic senators — Chuck Hagel and John McCain — shared a military background and a similar worldview, and they used to be close. What happened? Accounts differ.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the old days it was like a Senate buddy movie.

articles.headline: Sales of Guns Soar in U.S. as Nation Weighs Tougher Limits
articles.snippet: The rapid growth in gun sales began after President Obama’s re-election and surged after the Dec. 14 shooting at a school in Newtown, Conn.
articles.abstract: The rapid growth in gun sales began after President Obama’s re-election and surged after the Dec. 14 shooting at a school in Newtown, Conn.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Washington focuses on what Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will propose next week to curb gun violence, gun and ammunition sales are spiking in the rest of the country as people rush to expand their arsenals in advance of any restrictions that might be imposed.

articles.headline: Over 50, and Under No Illusions
articles.snippet: Many people aged 55 to 64, who had been dreaming of easy retirement, have had to remake their lives to find work during the recession and its aftermath.
articles.abstract: Many people aged 55 to 64, who had been dreaming of easy retirement, have had to remake their lives to find work during the recession and its aftermath.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S a baby boomer’s nightmare. One moment you’re 40-ish and moving up, the next you’re 50-plus and suddenly, shockingly, moving out — jobless in a tough economy.

articles.headline: A Desert Cold and Wet Multiplies the Misery of Syrian Refugees
articles.snippet: With aid agencies expecting Syrian refugees to reach 1 million in 2013, the misery in one camp highlights the humanitarian crisis that threatens to further destabilize the Middle East.
articles.abstract: With aid agencies expecting Syrian refugees to reach 1 million in 2013, the misery in one camp highlights the humanitarian crisis that threatens to further destabilize the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZAATARI, Jordan — The water has mostly been removed from hundreds of flooded tents and the dirt paths that run between them here in the region’s vastest camp of Syrian refugees. The clotheslines are laden with soggy sweaters and socks, waiting for the sun after a week of harsh wind, rain and snow.

articles.headline: Paying the Price, but Often Deducting It
articles.snippet: In many cases when the government reaches a financial settlement with a corporation, the companies later deduct the payments on their taxes.
articles.abstract: In many cases when the government reaches a financial settlement with a corporation, the companies later deduct the payments on their taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE numbers seem eye-popping. So many billions here for supposed mortgage abuses, so many billions there for questionable foreclosures.

articles.headline: A Soldier’s Requiem, Never Fading Away
articles.snippet: Jackie Finken and her daughters have gone through different phases of mourning for their lost husband and father. But they are all determined to remember, without letting memory become a millstone.
articles.abstract: Jackie Finken and her daughters have gone through different phases of mourning for their lost husband and father. But they are all determined to remember, without letting memory become a millstone.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOODBRIDGE, Va. — Each December, Jackie Finken pulls plastic bins from the basement and distributes carefully wrapped Christmas decorations to her three daughters. Each girl has her own ornaments. And each of those ornaments has a story. That is a Finken tradition, one of many.

articles.headline: Hawks on Iraq Prepare for War Again, Against Hagel
articles.snippet: The campaign now being waged against Senator Chuck Hagel’s nomination as secretary of defense echoes his dispute with fellow Republicans over the invasion of Iraq in 2003.
articles.abstract: The campaign now being waged against Senator Chuck Hagel’s nomination as secretary of defense echoes his dispute with fellow Republicans over the invasion of Iraq in 2003.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the bitter debate that led up to the American invasion of Iraq in 2003, Senator Chuck Hagel of Nebraska said that some of his fellow Republicans, in their zest for war, lacked the perspective of veterans like him, who have “sat in jungles or foxholes and watched their friends get their heads blown off.”

articles.headline: Obama Will Seek Citizenship Path in One Fast Push
articles.snippet: President Obama and Senate Democrats will try to carve a legislative path to citizenship for illegal immigrants with one comprehensive bill, resisting Republican proposals to tackle the issue piecemeal.
articles.abstract: President Obama and Senate Democrats will try to carve a legislative path to citizenship for illegal immigrants with one comprehensive bill, resisting Republican proposals to tackle the issue piecemeal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to push Congress to move quickly in the coming months on an ambitious overhaul of the immigration system that would include a path to citizenship for most of the 11 million illegal immigrants in the country, senior administration officials and lawmakers said last week.

articles.headline: Egyptian Court Rejects Verdict Against Mubarak
articles.snippet: While a court threw out Hosni Mubarak’s conviction for failing to prevent the deaths of protesters, the former Egyptian president is being held for investigation on other charges.
articles.abstract: While a court threw out Hosni Mubarak’s conviction for failing to prevent the deaths of protesters, the former Egyptian president is being held for investigation on other charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian appeals court on Sunday threw out the guilty verdict and life sentence against former President Hosni Mubarak on charges that he allowed the killing of protesters. The court ordered a new trial, which would once again send the ailing autocrat rolling on a stretcher into the steel defendant’s cage in an Egyptian criminal court.

articles.headline: China Again Is Growing, More Slowly
articles.snippet: After a sharp economic slowdown through much of last year, China’s economy is reviving, but with signs that inflation might become a problem again.
articles.abstract: After a sharp economic slowdown through much of last year, China’s economy is reviving, but with signs that inflation might become a problem again.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — After a sharp economic slowdown through much of last year, China’s economy is growing again — but not at its previous double-digit pace, and with signs that inflation might become a problem again.

articles.headline: After Rocky Year for Start-Ups, Investors Are Pickier
articles.snippet: The celebrated shift to smartphones, once welcomed with an outpouring of investments, is now making some investors nervous as monetization proves harder for mobile devices.
articles.abstract: The celebrated shift to smartphones, once welcomed with an outpouring of investments, is now making some investors nervous as monetization proves harder for mobile devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Call it the Facebook effect. Until recently, investors had been all too eager to pour millions into any Web start-up with rapid growth, regardless of whether it made money or even had plans to do so down the road. But after Facebook’s rocky initial public offering and flameouts at Zynga and Groupon, venture capitalists are entering a picky phase.

articles.headline: Google Gains From Creating Apps for the Opposition
articles.snippet: Google has become one of the most prolific developers of apps for the Apple iPhone, helping its rival even as their relationship worsens.
articles.abstract: Google has become one of the most prolific developers of apps for the Apple iPhone, helping its rival even as their relationship worsens.
articles.lead_paragraph: For many people, smartphone shopping comes down to a choice of Apple’s iPhone or one powered by Google’s Android software.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Guns, Maps and Data That Disturb
articles.snippet: Journalists create context by using sources who bring insight and provide analysis. Simply pointing out that something is public as the sole reason for publishing it is not a sufficient justification.
articles.abstract: Journalists create context by using sources who bring insight and provide analysis. Simply pointing out that something is public as the sole reason for publishing it is not a sufficient justification.
articles.lead_paragraph: Should data have a conscience?

articles.headline: Condé Nast Writer Deals Stir Dispute
articles.snippet: The publishing company is seeking film and television profits from articles that may become films and television programs, a plan that writers and agents say cuts into their shrinking compensation.
articles.abstract: The publishing company is seeking film and television profits from articles that may become films and television programs, a plan that writers and agents say cuts into their shrinking compensation.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s a dream tucked in the backs of many journalists’ minds: the article they write becomes a blockbuster movie and they reap a healthy share of the profits, a walk on the red carpet and — who knows? — maybe even an Oscar.

articles.headline: French Strikes in Mali Supplant Caution of U.S.
articles.snippet: France shoved aside months of international hesitation about storming the region after every other effort by the United States and its allies to thwart the extremists had failed.
articles.abstract: France shoved aside months of international hesitation about storming the region after every other effort by the United States and its allies to thwart the extremists had failed.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAMAKO, Mali — French fighter jets struck deep inside Islamist strongholds in northern Mali on Sunday, shoving aside months of international hesitation about storming the region after every other effort by the United States and its allies to thwart the extremists had failed.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter, Eric Schmitt and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Both Sides in Gun Debate Agree: Punish Background-Check Liars
articles.snippet: Facing opposition on many gun-control measures, the Obama administration is looking at prosecuting more people for misleading or lying to purchase a firearm.
articles.abstract: Facing opposition on many gun-control measures, the Obama administration is looking at prosecuting more people for misleading or lying to purchase a firearm.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly 80,000 Americans were denied guns in 2010, according to Justice Department data, because they lied or provided inaccurate information about their criminal histories on background-check forms. Yet only 44 of those people were charged with a crime.

articles.headline: A Data Crusader, a Defendant and Now, a Cause
articles.snippet: In his death, Aaron Swartz has come to symbolize a debate over cases against those who believe in “freeing” information.
articles.abstract: In his death, Aaron Swartz has come to symbolize a debate over cases against those who believe in “freeing” information.
articles.lead_paragraph: At an afternoon vigil at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on Sunday, Aaron Swartz, the 26-year-old technology wunderkind who killed himself on Friday, was remembered as a great programmer and a provocative thinker by a handful of students who attended.

articles.headline: In California, It’s U.S. vs. State Over Marijuana
articles.snippet: The case against Matthew R. Davies, who started a medical marijuana business, highlights the clash between the federal government and states that have legalized marijuana.
articles.abstract: The case against Matthew R. Davies, who started a medical marijuana business, highlights the clash between the federal government and states that have legalized marijuana.
articles.lead_paragraph: STOCKTON, Calif. — Matthew R. Davies graduated from college with a master’s degree in business and a taste for enterprise, working in real estate, restaurants and mobile home parks before seizing on what he saw as uncharted territory with a vast potential for profits — medical marijuana.

articles.headline: ‘South Park’ Creators to Start Company, Important Studios
articles.snippet: With an estimated value of $300 million, the studio will have the power and money to approve television, movie and theater projects, including a big-screen version of “The Book of Mormon.”
articles.abstract: With an estimated value of $300 million, the studio will have the power and money to approve television, movie and theater projects, including a big-screen version of “The Book of Mormon.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The creators of “South Park” are branching out beyond the underpants business.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Amy Chozick
